abstract: Many companies are enjoying record high valuations not because of strong results but because of investor optimism, Citigroup says in a new report. It has suggestions for bolstering earnings so that valuations are based not on wishful thinking but on the bottom line.

headline: What I Miss When I’m in China (and Arizona)
abstract: My dog is always ready to move on and look for something new. I can relate.

headline: You Sleep More Than You Claim You Do
abstract: When asked how much sleep they “usually” get, Americans estimate just 6.8 hours. When asked to document their sleep the night before, slumber time jumps to 8.7 hours.

headline: Artkick Wants to Be the Spotify of Art
abstract: A startup called Artkick has secured 50,000 digital representations of paintings and photographs from 2,000 museums around the world. It places them on Internet-connected televisions and computer screens.

headline: Today in Small Business: ‘Economic Freedom’
abstract: Small-business optimism rises. How to assess the health of your business. A reason to use Google Plus.

headline: Today’s Scuttlebot: Dorsey on Disrupting Receipts, and Implications of the Net Neutrality Ruling
abstract: Wednesday’s highlights from around the web include Jack Dorsey, while pitching his payments start-up, Square, arguing that the receipt is an untapped “canvas” and “publishing medium.” Plus, why the network neutrality ruling on Tuesday could matter to start-ups.

headline: A Village Takes Small Steps Toward Reconciliation After Muzaffarnagar Riots
abstract: Economic necessity has prompted talks in Fugana, Uttar Pradesh, between the Hindu Jats and the Muslim residents who fled after the violence that erupted in September.

headline: Finding Rewards, Financial and Spiritual, in E-Waste
abstract: Discarded consumer electronics are clogging landfills, fast-becoming a worldwide environmental calamity. One woman in Tulsa, Okla., is trying to make a dent.

abstract: As the World Economic Forum concludes in Davos, Switzerland, we’re looking back at some of our past coverage of the elite gathering.

abstract: As this year’s recruiting season begins, some college students say they are drawn to the challenge and fast-paced environment. Still others are, naturally, motivated by the high salaries that Wall Street offers.

abstract: Americans have tended to marry someone whose economic status is about the same as theirs, and that has contributed to growing income inequality in the United States.

abstract: In a panel discussion at the World Economic Forum on Friday, the top executives of MasterCard and the Western Union Company spoke about the escalating battle to keep financial transaction systems secure.

abstract: The focus of the investigation returned to two people on board with expertise — the pilot and his first officer.

abstract: With no obvious motive apparent, American investigators are considering a wide range of possibilities but caution that all remain merely speculative.

abstract: The first turn that diverted the missing Malaysia Airlines plane from its route was entered into a computer system, most likely by someone in the plane’s cockpit, American officials said.

abstract: Malaysia Airlines said Saturday morning that it had lost contact five hours earlier with a flight carrying at least 239 people to Beijing from Kuala Lumpur, and had activated a search-and-rescue team.

headline: For Myanmar Muslim Minority, No Escape From Brutality
abstract: Rohingya Muslims, denied citizenship in Myanmar, pass through Thailand on their way to relative safety in Malaysia or, if they cannot afford to pay unscrupulous brokers, languish there.

abstract: Soldiers gathered at the sliver of land separating Crimea and the rest of Ukraine leave little doubt that they have dug in for the long haul.

abstract: With models like the Bullet, an Indian-made avatar of an old British brand, Royal Enfield is making waves even as the competition for midsize bikes is heating up.

headline: Chinese Activists Test New Leader and Are Crushed
abstract: An anti-corruption group was heartened when China’s new president, Xi Jinping, came to power in 2012. Since then, their ideals have collided with a harsh reality.

headline: Deadly Attack at Kabul Restaurant Hints at Changing Climate for Foreigners
abstract: Kabul during the Afghan war was never violent as Baghdad during the Iraq war. But as coalition forces leave, international workers here feel more vulnerable.

headline: A Stampede of Mourners in India Kills at Least 18
abstract: Hundreds were packed into narrow lanes trying to get a glimpse of the body of the spiritual leader Syedna Mohammad Burhanuddin when the stampede occurred.

headline: Human Rights Watch Criticizes Inaction on Syria
abstract: In its annual report, Human Rights Watch said the desire to bring the Syrian government to peace talks should not be a pretext for failure to shield civilians.

headline: Oil Industry Nears a Big Asset Sell-Off
abstract: The deal may be one of many this year, as energy companies seek cash for other projects or to finance share buybacks and higher dividends.

headline: South Korea: Kidnapped Trade Official Is Rescued
abstract: Local security forces raided the kidnappers’ hide-out in the Libyan capital of Tripoli, the South Korean Foreign Ministry said.

headline: A Fed Policy Maker, Changing His Mind, Urges More Stimulus
abstract: Narayana Kocherlakota, president of the Minneapolis Fed, said the central bank should increase its efforts to stimulate the economy.

headline: Some States Are Moving to Loosen Their Estate Taxes
abstract: In 16 states, mostly in the North, state estate taxes ensnare the people the high federal exemption intended to protect.

headline: Court in Russia Says Associate of Ex-Oil Tycoon Should Be Freed
abstract: The order to free Platon A. Lebedev, a business associate of the recently pardoned oil tycoon Mikhail B. Khodorkovsky, was in step with a series of amnesties and pardons before the Winter Olympics.

headline: Official Targets ‘Russophobia’
abstract: Amid fears of conflict in Ukraine, a member of Parliament proposed a bill to penalize “Russophobic propaganda” in Russia, imposing penalties of 15 days in prison or a fine of about $1,370.

headline: End of Gulf Ban Allows BP to Expand in Familiar, Lucrative Territory
abstract: The chance to add new drilling sites in the Gulf of Mexico is a milestone in the company’s recovery from the Deepwater Horizon disaster.

headline: Sentence Cut for Bin Laden Figure
abstract: A doctor, convicted in Pakistan of treason for helping the C.I.A. track down Osama bin Laden, had 10 years cut from his 33-year sentence.

headline: In Colombia, Two Warring Officials Provide a Portrait of a Nation’s Political Divide
abstract: A conflict that arose after the country’s powerful inspector general ordered the mayor of Bogotá removed from office has captivated Colombians.

headline: Melba Hernández, a Confidante of Castro From First Volley, Is Dead at 92
abstract: Ms. Hernández became one of the first four members of Fidel Castro’s general staff and helped him during the Cuban revolution.

headline: A Pension Fund Invests Against the Rules, and Wins
abstract: While some call its strategy crazy, the Tampa firefighters and police officers pension fund has benefited from ignoring widely embraced investment doctrine.

headline: After 58 Years in a Couple, a Spouse Fights for Benefits
abstract: Some couples have been tripped up by bureaucratic rules concerning spousal benefits, despite the overturn last year of the federal law banning gay marriage.

headline: Ukraine Sets Deadline for Militias to Surrender Illegal Guns
abstract: So-called self-defense groups were ordered to disarm by Friday, the same day Ukraine is scheduled to sign the political articles of an association agreement with the European Union.

headline: Iranian Ship, in Plain View but Shrouded in Mystery, Looks Very Familiar to U.S.
abstract: Iran is building a nonworking mock-up of an American nuclear-powered aircraft carrier that United States officials say may be intended to be blown up for propaganda value.

headline: Teaching as a Second Act, or Maybe Even a Third
abstract: For those looking for a second or third career, teaching programs offer a variety of preparatory courses at different costs to get there.

headline: Federal Safety Agency Ends Its Investigation of Tesla Fires
abstract: The National Highway Traffic Safety Administration said steps taken by the automaker to better protect car batteries should reduce the risk of fire.

headline: Leo Bretholz, 93, Dies; Escaped Train to Auschwitz
abstract: Mr. Bretholz testified in Congress in 2011, asking that Holocaust survivors be allowed to sue the French railway S.N.C.F. for its role in Nazi deportations to death camps.

headline: U.S. Is Weighing Release of a Spy for the Israelis
abstract: The United States and Israel are discussing the possible release of Jonathan Pollard, an American serving a life sentence in North Carolina for spying for Israel.

headline: Auto Safety Agency Ready to Point Finger at G.M.
abstract: In testimony, a regulator will say that “critical” data from General Motors could have led to earlier detection of ignition flaws.

headline: Yellen Says Fed Is Determined to Improve the Labor Market
abstract: Ms. Yellen’s speech offered a strong reminder of her concern about unemployment, and a rebuttal to economists who fault the Fed’s ability to improve labor conditions.

headline: Converging Interests May Lead to Cooperation Between Israel and Gulf States
abstract: Widespread worry over Iran’s nuclear program and disagreement over American foreign policy have led to a new urgency to find common ground.

headline: French Voters Shift to the Right in Mayoral Elections
abstract: The poor showing by the Socialist Party is expected to lead to major changes to the government of François Hollande, including a cabinet reshuffle and a change in prime ministers.

headline: Journalists Held by Militants in Syria Reunite With Family
abstract: Javier Espinosa and Ricardo García Vilanova arrived in Madrid a day after Mr. Espinosa called his newspaper to say they had been handed over to Turkish soldiers.

headline: F.C.C. to Free Airwaves for Wi-Fi and Wireless Broadband
abstract: The commission is trying to ease the congestion that leads to dropped calls and slow loading of online material. It also acted to help curb the cost of cable television service.

headline: Iran: Surge in Executions Worries Rights Experts
abstract: Iran reportedly hanged 40 people in the first two weeks of January, 33 of them in the last week, leading United Nations human rights experts to call for a halt to the executions.

headline: Visiting Scene, Court Calls Forth Memories of Massacre at a Mall
abstract: A chief magistrate led a grim field trip to the Westgate mall in Nairobi, Kenya, the scene of a massacre, bringing along prosecutors, defense lawyers and even the suspects.

headline: The Elders of Organic Farming
abstract: For nearly a week, two dozen pioneers of sustainable agriculture from the United States and Canada shared decades’ worth of stories, secrets and anxieties.

headline: Thai Leaders Declare State of Emergency in Bangkok
abstract: The emergency decree gives the government broad powers against protesters, but Prime Minister Yingluck Shinawatra seemed to be moving cautiously.

headline: Top Wonkblog Columnist to Leave Washington Post
abstract: Ezra Klein, who is said to have been rebuffed by The Post when he asked it to back an online venture, oversaw the blog about government policy and wrote a column for it.

headline: Wartime Claim to Fame Divides 2 Italian Towns
abstract: Anzio is engraved in history books as the main landing site of forces that went on to liberate Rome. Now nearby Nettuno is seeking to stake its claim.

headline: Dawn Zier of Nutrisystem on When Your Company Is Adrift
abstract: This chief executive looks for employees who step up in times of change.

headline: Natural Gas Prices Soar as Mercury Plummets
abstract: Prices spiked by nearly 10 percent on Friday to the highest levels since 2010, as continuing frigid weather drove demand for heating and electricity.

headline: Asking Banks to Reveal Where Their High Rollers Are
abstract: The New York State comptroller wants banks to take an inventory of their risk-taking employees.

headline: The Tale of a House, and an Entire Market
abstract: The history of 12204 Backus Drive in Bowie, Md., is in many ways the history of the American housing market over the last two decades.

headline: Opposition Says No to Ukraine on Power Share
abstract: President Viktor F. Yanukovych offered to install opposition leaders in top government posts, but they swiftly rebuffed the offer, to the delight of thousands of protesters on the street.
